How do we know that the characteristics of conditioned phenomena are different from form, mind, etc., and have their own real nature?
Because it is said in the scriptures.
As a scripture says:
There are three characteristics of conditioned phenomena, and so on, in detail.
This sÅ«tra does not say that there is a real nature different from form, mind, etc., so your proof is not established.
The sixth sound does not necessarily indicate a different substance, because the substance of form and mind is just form and mind.
The substance of the characteristics is not necessarily different from the characterized, because the characteristics of solidity, etc., are not different from earth, etc.

If the characteristics of conditioned phenomena are different from the substance of the characterized, then the substance of the characteristics of unconditioned phenomena should be different from the characterized.
Moreover, if the characteristics such as arising exist simultaneously with the substance, then they should all function at the same time.
If they do not function all at once because they are mutually contradictory, then how can they exist simultaneously if their substances are mutually contradictory?

Also, the functions of abiding and cessation cannot occur simultaneously, because the substance of that which has a characteristic and that which possesses a characteristic are both originally existent.
The functions of these two must also be so, because they have no separate natures.
If it is said that these two functions must await causes and conditions, then the causes and conditions that are awaited cannot be originally existent.
Also, if it is held that arising, etc., are useless, and that that which has characteristics always exists and is united with arising, etc.,
then dharmas that are unconditioned must also have arising, etc., because the reason for the difference between these two cannot be found.
Also, the future and past are not present and not permanent, and must be like a flower in the sky and not really existent.
Arising is called existence. How can it be in the future?
Cessation is called nonexistence. It must not be present.
If cessation is not nonexistence, then arising must be existence.
Also, if cessation is contrary to abiding, how can it be held that they occur simultaneously?
If abiding is not contrary to arising, how can they be in different times?
Therefore the characteristics of the conditioned are neither advanced nor reasonable.

However, because of the power of causes and conditions, dharmas that are conditioned do not exist previously but are now existent, are temporarily existent, and then return to nonexistence. In order to distinguish them from the unconditioned, the four characteristics of arising, etc., are conventionally established.
Existence in the state of having had no prior existence is called birth.
The temporary suspension of the state of existence is called duration.
The distinction of prior and subsequent in the state of duration is again called old age.
The temporary existence that returns to nonexistence is called extinction.
The first three exist, and therefore they are categorized as present. The last one is nonexistent, and therefore it is categorized as past.
How can something nonexistent be a characteristic of something existent?
What is wrong with taking the future nonexistence of something as its characteristic?

Birth indicates that a dharma was previously nonexistent, and extinction indicates that a dharma will be nonexistent later. Old age indicates that this dharma is not static, and duration indicates that this dharma has a temporary function. Therefore, although these four characteristics are all called indications of the conditioned, there is a difference in what they indicate.
These four characteristics are provisionally established on the basis of a single moment. They can also be provisionally established on the basis of a period of time in the life of a dharma.

The first moment is called birth, the last is called extinction, the continuity of similar moments is called duration, and the transformation of this continuity is called old age. Therefore, the four characteristics are all provisionally established.
How do you know that there are real name, phrase, and syllable apart from form, mind, etc.?
Because it is said in the scriptures.
A scripture says,
The Buddha has obtained the marvelous names, phrases, and syllables.
This scripture does not say that apart from form and mind there are real names, etc., so your proof is inconclusive.
If names, phrases, and syllables are really different from sound, they must be like form, etc., and not really able to express.
That is, if sound generates names, phrases, and syllables, then this sound must have a melody and a rhythm, and this is sufficient to express, so what need is there for names, etc.?

If you say that the melody and rhythm in sound are names, phrases, and syllables, and that they are different from sound and really exist, then you must admit that the shape and size of visible form are different from the visible form base and have real substance.

If you say that the melody and rhythm in sound, like the sound of a stringed instrument, are not able to express, then sound should not generate names, etc., just as the sound of a stringed instrument does not.
Moreover, who says that sound is definitely unable to express?

If sound is able to express meaning, then the sound of wind chimes, etc., should have the function of expressing meaning, and this should be like that, not producing a real collection of names, phrases, and syllables.
If only the sound of speech can produce names, etc., why not allow that speech alone can express meaning?
What principle determines that that which expresses meaning is speech? How do you know that that which expresses meaning is different from speech?

Speech is not different from that which expresses meaning. This is understood by both humans and gods. The attachment to the idea that that which expresses meaning is different from speech is loved by the gods, not by others.

However, names, phrases, and syllables are established by imputation based on the distinctions in the states of the sound of speech. Names express intrinsic nature, phrases express distinctions, and letters are the basis of the other two.
Although these three are not separate from sound and do not have a separate substance, they are different in being imputed and real, and they are also not the same as sound.

For this reason, the objects of the two unobstructed abilities of teaching and understanding the Dharma are different. Sound and names, etc., are categorized as aggregates, sense bases, and sense fields in different ways.

Moreover, we say that names, phrases, and syllables are established on the basis of sound only in this world, not in all places, because in other buddha lands the three are established on the basis of light, wonderful smells, tastes, etc.
There is an opinion that propensities are different from mind and its activities and are included in the aggregate of formations not associated with mind.
This also is unreasonable, because they are called craving, etc., just as actual craving, etc., are not not associated with mind.
Other dharmas not associated with mind that are held to exist should be refuted in the same way.
It is impossible to establish the existence of real, separate, unconditioned dharmas apart from form, mind, etc.
There are, in general, three kinds of existent dharmas:
1. dharmas that are known in the present, such as form, mind, etc.;
2. dharmas that are used in the present, such as pots, clothes, etc.;
these two kinds of dharmas are known to exist in the world and do not have to be established by reasoning;
3. dharmas that have function, such as eyes, ears, etc., which are known to exist because of their various functions.

Unconditioned dharmas are not definitely known to exist by the world in general, and they do not function like eyes, ears, etc. Even if you admit that they function, they must be impermanent. Therefore, you cannot maintain that unconditioned dharmas definitely exist.

However, because unconditioned dharmas are the nature of knowables, or because they are manifested by form, mind, etc., like form and mind, etc., you cannot maintain that they are unconditioned dharmas that are real substances apart from form and mind, etc.
Also, are such dharmas as space one or many?
If their substance is one and they are omnipresent,
then space must be many, because it must be the same substance as the dharmas that it contains.
If it is not so, then dharmas must interpenetrate.
If you claim that space does not combine with dharmas, then it must not contain them, just like other unconditioned dharmas.
Also, is there space within form, etc.?
If there is, then it must be mixed with form, etc., and if there is not, then it is not omnipresent.
When the bonds of a single category and stage are eliminated, one must obtain cessation resulting from discrimination of other categories and stages.
When one dharma is not produced because its conditions are lacking, it should be possible to obtain non-analytical cessation with regard to all dharmas.
If you maintain that its substance is one, this must be so.

If its substance is many, then it must have varieties and must be like form, etc., and not a real unconditioned dharma. Space must also not be all-pervading and must not be able to accommodate and receive.
The real unconditioned dharmas grasped by other Buddhist schools must be refuted in the same way.
Also, because unconditioned dharmas are said to have no causes or effects, they must be like the horns of a rabbit and not exist apart from mind, etc.
However, a scripture says that there is space, etc.
Unconditioned dharmas are of two kinds.

One is that which is provisionally established as existing on the basis of transformations of consciousness, that is, having heard the name space, etc., one discriminates the characteristics of space, etc., and because of the power of habit, when mind, etc., is born, it appears in the form of the characteristics of space, etc., as unconditioned dharmas.
The characteristics that appear are similar before and after and do not change, and it is provisionally said that they are permanent.

The second is that of the provisional establishment of existence in dependence on the nature of dharmas, that is, true suchness revealed by emptiness and nonself, which is neither existent nor nonexistent, and beyond the path of mind and words. It is neither identical with nor different from all dharmas, and is the reality of dharmas, and for that reason it is called the nature of dharmas. It is free of all obstacles and for that reason it is called space.
It is called cessation resulting from discrimination because it is finally realized through the power of the discernment of the four noble truths.
It is called cessation not resulting from discrimination because it is pure by nature, whether or not conditions are absent, or because it is revealed by the absence of conditions.
It is called immovable because it is the cessation of the feelings of pleasure and suffering.
It is called cessation of ideation and feeling because ideation and feeling do not function.

All five of these are established as provisional realities in dependence on true suchness. True suchness is also a provisional reality. It is said to exist in order to refute the nihilistic view that it does not exist, and it is said to be empty in order to refute the view that it exists.

Do not say that because it is empty and illusory, it is said to be real. It is called true suchness because its principle is not false or inverted, unlike the doctrines of other schools that say that apart from form and mind, etc., there is a real, permanent dharma called true suchness. Therefore the various unconditioned dharmas do not definitely really exist.

The various dharmas grasped at by non-Buddhists and other Buddhist schools, which are different from mind and mental activities, do not really exist, because they are objects of grasping, like mind and mental activities.
The consciousness that grasps them also does not perceive them, because it is the agent of grasping,

like the consciousnesses and mental activities that perceive this consciousness, because they are produced in dependence on others, and also because they are like magical creations, and therefore do not really exist.
In order to eliminate the false grasping of external objects apart from mind and mental activities, it is said that there is only consciousness.
If you grasp at the idea that consciousness alone really exists, this is also the attachment to dharmas as expounded by other Buddhist schools.
There are, however, two kinds of attachment to dharmas.
The first is innate, and the second is resulting from discrimination.

The innate grasping of dharmas has been perfumed since beginningless time by the power of internal causes, and it is always associated with the body. It does not depend on false teachings or discrimination, and it evolves spontaneously. Therefore it is called innate.
It is of two kinds.

The first is always in a state of continuity and is located in the seventh consciousness. It takes as its object the eighth consciousness and generates its own mental image, grasping it as a real dharma.

The second is sometimes in a state of continuity and is located in the sixth consciousness. It takes as its object the aggregates, sense bases, and sense fields as transformed by consciousness, either in general or in particular, and generates its own mental image, grasping it as a real dharma.

This twofold grasping of dharmas is subtle and therefore difficult to eliminate. It is eliminated only by repeated cultivation of the superior contemplation of the emptiness of dharmas during the ten stages of bodhisattva development.

The discriminating grasping of dharmas is due to the power of present external conditions and is not associated with the body. It occurs only after false teachings and discrimination. Therefore it is called discriminating.
It exists only in the sixth, mental consciousness.
It is also of two kinds.

The first is the appearance of oneâ€™s own mind that arises in regard to the characteristics of the aggregates, sense bases, and sense fields as taught in false teachings, and the discrimination and conceptualization that grasps them as real dharmas.

The second is the appearance of oneâ€™s own mind that arises in regard to the characteristics of intrinsic nature, etc., as taught in false teachings, and the discrimination and conceptualization that grasps them as real dharmas.

These two forms of grasping at dharmas are coarse and therefore easy to eliminate. When one enters the first stage, one contemplates the true suchness of the emptiness of dharmas in all dharmas and is able to eliminate them.

All of the above-mentioned forms of grasping at dharmas are either existent or nonexistent in regard to external dharmas of oneâ€™s own mind. All of them exist in regard to internal dharmas of oneâ€™s own mind. Therefore, grasping at dharmas all grasps as really existent the dharmas that appear from oneâ€™s own mind.
However, the appearances of dharmas are produced from conditions and therefore are like illusions.
The real dharmas that are grasped are falsely imagined and therefore definitely do not exist.
Therefore the World Honored One said:
Maitreya, you should know that the objects of consciousness are only the appearances of consciousness, the nature of dependent arising, like illusions, etc.

Therefore mind and its activities definitely do not use external form, etc., as objects of perception, because the function of an object of perception must be based on a real substance.ğŸ”½The mind and mental activities of a present group of consciousnesses are not the object of perception of the consciousness of another group, because they are not objects of perception, being included in another group.
Mental activities of the same group also are not its object of perception, because they are different from the substance of consciousness, just like other dharmas that are not grasped.
Consequently, you must understand that there really are no external objects, and that internal consciousness arises resembling external objects.
Therefore a verse from the GhanavyÅ«ha SÅ«tra says,
External objects are really nonexistent, as imagined by the ignorant. The mind is disturbed by perfuming and therefore evolves resembling them.
There is an objection to this.
If there are no real selves and dharmas apart from consciousness, then the imaginary must also not exist.

That is, the nominal must be established in dependence on real things, similar things, and common attributes. For example, only when there is real fire, a person who is similar to fire, and the attribute of fieriness can one metaphorically say that the person is fire. The same is so for the metaphorical designation of cow, etc.
If there are no real selves and dharmas, what are we metaphorically designating?
Since there is no metaphorical designation, the similar also does not exist. How can you say that mind evolves resembling external objects?

This objection is unreasonable, because we have already refuted the existence of selves and dharmas apart from consciousness.ğŸ”½The metaphorical designation of fire, etc., in dependence on a class or a real thing is not established in either case.ğŸ”½The first case is not established, because the attributes of fieriness, redness, etc., do not exist in a class. If one metaphorically designates something in the absence of common attributes, one should also metaphorically designate water, etc., as fire, etc.

If you claim that even though fieriness, etc., are not attributes of a class, they are inseparable from it and therefore can be metaphorically designated, this is also not so, because we see that fieriness, etc., are sometimes absent in a class.

Since the class has no qualities and the two are mutually exclusive, still we provisionally speak of fire in reference to a person. Therefore we know that provisional positing does not depend on the class.
The principle of depending on the real to provisionally posit is also not established, because the qualities of fieriness, redness, etc., are not common to both.
This is because the fieriness, redness, etc., of fire and the fieriness, redness, etc., of a person are each different, because their bases are different.
There is no commonality, and the error is the same as before.

If you say that the qualities of a person and fire are similar and therefore one can provisionally speak of fire in reference to a person, this is also not reasonable, because speaking of fire in reference to a person is not speaking of it in reference to its qualities. Therefore provisional positing is not established as depending on the real.

Also, the principle that the provisional necessarily depends on the real to be established is also unreasonable, because the real refers to the specific characteristic, and neither knowledge nor expression can be its object.

This is because knowledge and expression do not obtain the specific characteristic, but only occur in reference to the common characteristic of dharmas. Also, apart from this there is no other method to establish the specific characteristic as the basis of the provisional.
However, knowledge and expression of the provisional necessarily arise in dependence on sound, and where sound does not reach, they do not occur.
Both the means and objects of expression are not the specific characteristics of things, and therefore we know that the conventional expressions do not depend on real things.
Therefore, they only occur in dependence on things that are similar to real things. Similar means added, not really existing.
Sound occurs in dependence on the added, similar characteristics, and therefore it cannot be said that the conventional necessarily depends on the real. Therefore, the objection is not reasonable.

However, in order to eliminate the false grasping of real selves and dharmas, we speak conventionally of the similar in dependence on the transformation of consciousness. A verse in the scriptures says,ğŸ”½In order to eliminate the grasping of fools,
The names of real selves and dharmas,
We speak conventionally of selves and dharmas In dependence on the transformation of consciousness.
Although the characteristics of the transformation of consciousness are innumerable, the classes of transforming consciousnesses are only three:
The first is called retribution, which is the eighth consciousness, because its nature is that of retribution for actions.
The second is called thought, which is the seventh consciousness, because it always reflects on and judges.
The third is called perception, which is the first six consciousnesses, because their mode of activity is coarse.
The phrase and so on indicates that the six are of one kind.
These three are called evolving consciousnesses for two reasons:

First, they are evolving causes, that is, the two causes of habit energy and the cause of retribution in the eighth consciousness. Habit energy of the same species is perfumed by good, bad, and indeterminate dharmas in the first seven consciousnesses and is caused to grow. Habit energy of retribution is perfumed by impure good and bad dharmas in the first six consciousnesses and is caused to grow.
Second, they are evolving results, that is, the various evolving actual dharmas and seeds that result from the power of the two causes of habit energy.

Because of the habit energy of the same species as a condition, the substance and characteristics of the eight consciousnesses are born with distinctions. This is called the result of the same species, because the result is similar to the cause.

Because of the habit energy of retribution as a dominant condition, the eighth consciousness, as retribution, is born and continues in a series, in accordance with the power of the projected action. Therefore it is called retribution.

The first six consciousnesses, as retribution, are born from the retribution of the eighth consciousness in accordance with the power of the action that perfects the result. They are called born of retribution.
They are not called retribution, because they are interrupted.
The above-mentioned retribution and that born of retribution are called the fruit of retribution, because the fruit differs from its cause.
Here, the consciousness that holds the seeds of the impure dharmas and is grasped by the attachment to a self is called retribution, but this does not mean all consciousnesses are retribution.
Although the names of the three consciousnesses that transform have been briefly explained, their characteristics have not yet been discussed.
What are the characteristics of the first transforming consciousness?
A verse says,
The first is called Älaya consciousness, Retribution, and all seeds.
It always perceives and is associated with Mental contact, manas, feeling, conceptualization, and volition. Its mode is that of indifference.
Mental contact, etc., are also like this.
It evolves like a flowing stream, and is abandoned in the state of arhatship.

The Treatise says that the first transforming consciousness is called Älaya by the teachings of both Mahayana and HÄ«nayÄna, because it is characterized by the ability to store, to be stored, and to grasp as a self. That is, it is the cause of the impure dharmas and is in turn their result, and sentient beings grasp it as an inner self.ğŸ”½It is called retribution because it is the result of impure good and bad actions. It is called all seeds because it is the seed of all dharmas.
This shows the nature of the first transforming consciousness, because the cause and effect it holds are its nature.
Although there are many states of this consciousness, the store consciousness is the most important, and therefore it is mentioned first.
It is called retribution because it is the result of good and bad action that attracts the various realms, destinies, and births.

Apart from this life root, the superior result of retribution, which is the homogeneous existence of beings, cannot be found as a continuous series. This shows the result aspect of the first transforming consciousness.
Although there are many states and kinds of results of this consciousness, retribution is broad and not shared by other consciousnesses, and therefore it is mentioned first.

It is called possessing all the seeds because it holds the seeds of all dharmas and prevents their loss. Apart from this consciousness, there is no other dharma that can be found that holds the seeds of all dharmas.
This shows the cause aspect of the first transforming consciousness.
Although there are many kinds of causes of this consciousness, holding seeds is not shared by other dharmas, and therefore it is mentioned first.
Although the essence and characteristics of the first transforming consciousness are many, in brief there are only these three characteristics.

What is the meaning of the word â€˜seedâ€™?

It is the power or ability in the root consciousness that immediately produces its own results. This power is neither the same as nor different from the root consciousness and its results, because the principles of substance and function and cause and effect require this.
Although it is neither the same as nor different from them, it really exists, because a fictional dharma does not exist and is not a condition.
Since it is neither the same as nor different from dharmas, it must be like a pot, etc., and be fictional, not real.
If this is so, then suchness must be a fiction.
If you admit this, then there is no true, supreme truth. However, seeds are said to be real only in the conventional sense, unlike suchness.

Even though seeds are supported by the substance of the eighth consciousness, they are the seen part of this consciousness and not the seeing part, because the seeing part always takes them as its object.
All impure seeds are categorized as indeterminate, because they are not different from the substance of consciousness as retribution.
Because both the cause and fruit are categorized as being good, etc., they are also called good, etc.
Because the various pure seeds are not categorized as the nature of the result of retribution, and because both cause and fruit are categorized as the nature of good, they are called good only.
If this is so, why does the ViniÅ›cayasaá¹ƒgraha say that the twenty-two faculties all have seeds as retribution and are born of retribution?

Even though they are called retribution, they are not indeterminate. They are called seeds of retribution because they are supported by retribution, just as visual consciousness, etc., are supported by the material organs.
Or, pure seeds are called retribution because they are transformed and mature through the power of perfuming, but they are not categorized as retribution that is indeterminate in nature.
There is an interpretation by Sthiramati that all seeds exist naturally and are not born from perfuming, but they can increase through the power of perfuming.
A scripture says,
Since beginningless time all sentient beings have within them various kinds of elements that are like seeds in a myrobalan fruit, existing naturally.
Elements are synonymous with seeds.
A scripture says:
Since beginningless time it has been the support of all dharmas.
The word dhÄtu means cause.
The YogÄcÄrabhÅ«mi SÄstra says, The substance of seeds has always existed naturally, but it is perfumed and produces new seeds.
All sentient beings since beginningless time have all the seeds, but those who will never enter nirvana lack the three kinds of bodhi seeds.
There are many such passages.
Also, since sentient beings are said to have five different natures from beginningless time, there must be naturally existing seeds that are not born from perfuming.
Also, the YogÄcÄrabhÅ«mi SÄstra says:
Hell beings possess three pure faculties, but they are seeds, not actual faculties.
Also, they are acquired naturally and transmitted from beginningless time, and they are innate by nature.
On the basis of these passages, we conclude that pure seeds exist naturally and are not born from perfuming.
Seeds of impure dharmas must also exist by the nature of things, but they increase through perfuming and are not born through perfuming.
In this way, cause and effect are established without confusion.

There is an interpretation that all seeds are born through perfuming, and that the perfumed and the perfumer both exist from beginningless time, and consequently all seeds are accomplished from beginningless time.
Since seeds are a synonym for habit energy, habit energy must exist through perfuming, just as sesame oil is born through the perfuming of sesame flowers.
As a scripture teaches,
The minds of sentient beings are perfumed by impure and pure dharmas and consequently accumulate an infinity of seeds.
A treatise says, Internal seeds definitely result from perfuming, but external seeds may or may not result from perfuming.
Also, the three kinds of perfuming, i.e., names and expressions, etc., totally include all impure seeds.
Since these three exist through perfuming, impure seeds are born through perfuming.

Seeds of the pure class are also born from perfuming, because they are perfumed and produced by hearing the pure dharmadhÄtu and the correct teaching that flows from it, and because they are by nature the seeds of supramundane mind.
The original differences in the spiritual genes of sentient beings are due not to the presence or absence of pure seeds, but to the presence or absence of obstacles.
As the YogÄcÄrabhÅ«mi ÅšÄstra teaches,
If one definitely has the seeds of the two obstacles of the realm of reality, he is classified as having the spiritual gene of non-rebirth.

If one definitely has the seeds of the obstacle to that which is to be known but not the seeds of the passions, he is classified as having the spiritual gene of the two vehicles, and if he does not have the seeds of the obstacle to that which is to be known, he is classified as having the spiritual gene of the TathÄgata.
Therefore, we know that the original differences in spiritual genes are established on the basis of the presence or absence of obstacles, not on the basis of pure seeds.
The statement that one is provided with pure seeds is based on the fact that they can be born, not on the fact that they already exist.
There is an interpretation that the seeds are of two kinds:
The first is innate, which means that since beginningless time there have been in the store consciousness differences in the power of dharmas to produce aggregates, sense bases, and sense fields.
The World Honored One, relying on this, said that sentient beings since beginningless time have various seeds, like seeds in a fruit, that exist naturally.
The other scriptures that support this are explained in detail in the first chapter.
This is called the seeds that exist naturally.
The second is newly acquired, which means that since beginningless time, perfuming has occurred repeatedly.
The World Honored One, relying on this, said that the mind of sentient beings is perfumed by defiled and pure dharmas, and therefore accumulates seeds of innumerable kinds.
The treatises also say that defiled and pure seeds are born from the perfuming of defiled and pure dharmas.
This is called the seeds that are perfumed and acquired.
If seeds only exist naturally, the evolving consciousnesses should not be the cause and condition of the store consciousness.
As a scripture says:
Dharmas are stored in consciousness, and consciousness is in dharmas.
They are also the nature of cause for each other and are also always the nature of cause.
The meaning of this verse is that the Älaya consciousness and the other evolving consciousnesses are born by transformation from each other at all times and are cause and effect for each other.
The MahÄyÄnasaá¹ƒgraha says,

The Älaya consciousness and the impure dharmas are causes for each other, like a candle and its flame, which arise and burn by mutual support. Also, they are like bundles of reeds that stand by mutual support.
Only on the basis of these two is the principle of causality established, because other principles of causality cannot be found.
If seeds are not born from perfuming, how can the evolving consciousnesses be a condition as cause for the Älaya?
It is not necessary that perfuming produce growth in order to be a condition as cause, because it would be necessary that good and bad action be a condition as cause for the result of retribution.
Also, the holy teachings that say that seeds are born from perfuming all contradict this opinion. Therefore, the opinion that seeds are only acquired contradicts reason and the holy teachings.
If seeds are only produced at the beginning of time, then conditioned, pure dharmas would not be born, because they would have no condition as cause.
Impure dharmas should not be the seeds of pure dharmas, because it is not possible for pure seeds to produce impure dharmas.
If you admit that impure dharmas are the seeds of pure dharmas, then you must admit that pure dharmas are the seeds of impure dharmas.

The VibhÄá¹£Ä ÅšÄstra says that mind is by nature pure, but it is defiled by the adventitious defilements of the passions. Therefore it is said to be defiled. When it is free of the passions, it is transformed into pure mind. Therefore pure dharmas are not born without a cause.
What does the phrase the nature of mind mean?
If it means the principle of emptiness, emptiness is not the cause of mind, because a permanent dharma definitely cannot be the seed of dharmas, because its substance does not change before or after.

If it means mind itself, then you are the same as the SÄá¹ƒkhyas, who say that although the characteristics of the primary one change, the substance is always the same. Also, evil and indeterminate minds would be good.

If you admit this, then you must admit that they are associated with faith and the other good dharmas. If you do not admit this, then they are not the substance of good mind. They are not even good, so how could they be pure?

Since impure good minds are called defiled, they are by nature not pure, like evil minds, etc., and therefore they should not be causes of pure minds, because good and evil, etc., should not be reciprocal causes.
If impure minds are by nature pure, then pure minds should be by nature impure, because there is no basis for distinguishing them.
Also, if the minds of ordinary beings are pure, then the actual pure dharmas that appear in the stage of ordinary beings should be called holy.

If the nature of the minds of ordinary beings is pure but their characteristics are defiled, and this is not a mistake, then the seeds of mind are also not pure. Why does your treatise say that there are ordinary beings who only possess pure seeds?
Because the nature of seeds and actual dharmas is the same.
However, a scripture says that the nature of mind is pure, but this means that mind is the suchness revealed by emptiness, because suchness is the true nature of mind.

Or, it is said that the substance of mind is not defiled, and therefore it is said that its nature is pure by nature, but it is not that the nature of a contaminated mind is pure and therefore it is said to be pure by nature.

Consequently, you should believe that all sentient beings from beginningless time have uncontaminated seeds that are naturally perfected and not created by perfuming, and that in the state of superior progress they are perfumed and made to increase and grow.
Uncontaminated dharmas arise using these seeds as a cause, and when uncontaminated dharmas arise, they perfume and create new seeds.
You should understand that contaminated dharmas are similar to this.

Even though holy teachings say that internal seeds definitely have perfuming, they do not definitely say that all seeds are born from perfuming. How can you completely deny the existence of innate seeds?
However, innate seeds are made to increase and grow through perfuming and are then able to produce results. Therefore the holy teachings say that internal seeds definitely have perfuming.

The perfuming of hearing is not only impure, for when one hears the true Dharma, it also perfumes the originally existing seeds of the pure part and causes them to gradually increase and strengthen, and this continues until the supramundane mind is born. Therefore it is also called the perfuming of hearing.
The perfuming of hearing is of two kinds: that which is impure in nature is eliminated by cultivation, attracts superior rewards, and is the dominant condition for the supramundane dharmas.
That which is pure in nature is not eliminated, and is the direct cause of the supramundane dharmas.
This direct cause is subtle and hidden and difficult to perceive. It is provisionally said to be the seed of the supramundane mind, using the coarse and obvious dominant condition.
As for the establishment of the differences of gotra based on the obstacles, it is a matter of the presence or absence of pure seeds.
That is, if one is completely devoid of pure seeds, the seeds of the two obstacles can never be destroyed, and one is established as a person who will never attain nirvÄá¹‡a.

If they possess only impure seeds of the two vehicles, the seeds of the obstacle to that which is to be known are eternally indestructible, and they are established as having the spiritual gene of the two vehicles.
If they also possess pure seeds of Buddhahood, the seeds of the two obstacles can be destroyed, and they are established as having the spiritual gene of TathÄgatas.
Therefore, the meaning of the destructibility or non-destructibility of the obstacles is due to the presence or absence of pure seeds.
However, pure seeds are subtle and hard to know, and therefore the differences in spiritual genes are revealed on the basis of the obstacles.
Otherwise, what is the specific cause of the obstacles, such that they are sometimes destructible and sometimes not?
If it is said that the obstacles exist by the nature of things, but the pure seeds of dharmas do not, why not admit the same for the obstacles?

If one originally lacks pure seeds of dharmas, then the holy path can never be produced. Who can destroy the seeds of the two obstacles? How can you say that the differences in spiritual genes are established on the basis of the obstacles?
Since the holy path can never be produced, it is also definitely unreasonable to say that it can be produced.

However, the teachings of the scriptures, which say that there are seeds that exist by nature, all contradict the theory of origination from the beginningless past. Therefore, the theory of origination from the beginningless past contradicts reason and the teachings.
Consequently, you should understand that the seeds of dharmas are of two kinds, existing by nature and originating from somewhere.
There are six kinds of seeds:
1. Perishing in a moment. That is, the substance of the seed is born and immediately perishes, and only that which has superior power can be a seed.
This excludes eternal dharmas, because they are always unchanging and cannot be said to have the function of generating.
2. Existing simultaneously with the result. That is, the seed exists simultaneously with the present result that it generates, and only that which is united with the result can be a seed.

This excludes seeds that are simultaneous or that are definitely separated from each other. Present seeds and dharmas of different species do not exclude each other. In one body, they can exist simultaneously and have the function of generating, unlike seeds of the same species that generate each other, which are mutually exclusive and cannot exist simultaneously.
Even though cause and result may or may not exist simultaneously, only when present can the cause have a function, because that which has not yet been born or has already perished has no substance.

The name seed is established on the basis of the production of present results, not on the basis of the production of its own species. Therefore it should be said that it exists simultaneously with its result.
The third characteristic is that of constant CONCOMITANCE, that is, it must be a homogeneous, continuous series that lasts until the end of existence before it can be a seed.
This excludes the evolving consciousnesses, which are interrupted and do not conform to the nature of seeds. This shows that seeds of the same species produce each other.
The fourth characteristic is that of definite BIOLOGICAL POTENTIALITY, that is, it must have the definite potential to produce a result in accordance with its cause before it can be a seed.
This excludes the theory of other Buddhist schools that causes of different species can produce results of different species through a causal relation.
The fifth characteristic is that of requiring a collection of conditions, that is, it must be the special power of the collection of conditions for the appearance of a seed before it can be a seed.
This excludes the theory of non-Buddhists that natural causes produce results suddenly without requiring a collection of conditions.
Or it excludes the theory of other Buddhist schools that conditions are never absent.
This shows that the required conditions are not always present, and therefore seeds do not always suddenly produce results.
The sixth is that of attracting its own fruit, that is, attracting and producing separately the various fruits of form, mind, etc. only then does it become a seed.
This excludes the heterodox doctrine that a single cause produces all results.
Or it excludes the doctrine of other Buddhist schools that form and mind, etc., are causes of each other.
Only the differences of potentialities in the fundamental consciousness have these six meanings and are seeds, not other dharmas.
External seeds such as grain, etc., are transformations of consciousness and are metaphorically referred to as seeds, but they are not real seeds.

The power of these seeds to produce a proximate, direct result is called the cause of birth, and the ability to attract a distant, residual result and prevent its sudden cessation is called the cause of continuation.
Internal seeds must be born and grow through perfuming, and they are the direct cause of results.
External seeds may or may not be perfumed, and they are the dominant condition.
In producing results, internal seeds are the direct cause, because the results produced by seeds of common characteristics are results of the same species.
What is the meaning of the term perfuming ?
The object of perfuming and the perfumer must each have four qualities in order for seeds to be born and grow, and for this reason they are called perfuming.
What are the four qualities of the object of perfuming?
1. The quality of stability. A dharma that is uniform and continuous from beginning to end and that can hold habitual energy is perfumable.
This excludes the evolving consciousnesses and sound, wind, etc., because their natures are not stable and therefore they are not perfumable.
2. The quality of being indeterminate. A dharma that is equal and uniform and does not resist is perfumable because it can contain habitual energy.
This excludes the wholesome and defiled natures, because their power is strong and they do not contain anything.
Consequently, the pure eighth consciousness of a TathÄgata only possesses old seeds and does not newly receive perfuming.
3. The quality of being perfumable. A dharma that is independent and whose nature is not hard and solid can receive habitual energy and is therefore perfumable.
This excludes mental activities and unconditioned dharmas, because they are hard and solid in dependence on something else and therefore are not perfumable.

Fourth, it must be of the same substance as the perfumer, that is, it must be simultaneous with and occupy the same location as the perfumer, and it must not be separate from it. Only then can it be perfumed.
This excludes other bodies, which are not of the same substance as the perfumer, and also excludes past and future states, which are not simultaneous with the perfumer.
Only the eighth consciousness, which is perfumable, possesses these four characteristics. Mental activities and other dharmas do not.
What are the four characteristics of the perfumer?
First, it must be subject to birth and death. A dharma that is not permanent can perform actions and generate and nurture the seeds of habit energy. It is the perfumer.
This excludes the unconditioned dharmas, which are changeless before and after and do not have the function of nurturing and growing.
Second, it must have a powerful function. It must have the power to generate and destroy and to attract habit energy. It is the perfumer.
This excludes the eighth consciousness and mental activities of the sixth consciousness in the three evil destinies, which are weak and not perfumers.
Third, it must be able to increase and decrease. It must be able to increase and decrease the seeds of habit energy. It is the perfumer.
This excludes the Buddhaâ€™s result, because perfect good dharmas have no increase or decrease and therefore cannot be perfumers.
If they could perfume, they would not be perfect, and the results of the Buddhas of the three times would be superior or inferior.
Fourth, it must be associated with the perfumed and occur together with it.
If it occurs simultaneously with the perfumed and in the same place, and is neither identical with nor separate from it, then it can perfume.
This excludes other bodies, because there is no association between them and the consciousness that perfumes.
Only the first seven consciousnesses and their mental activities, which have a powerful function that increases and decreases, have these four meanings and can perfume.
In this way, the perfumer and the perfumed consciousness are born together and perish together, and the perfuming is successful.
It causes the seeds in the perfumed to be born and grow, just as sesame is perfumed by flowers, and for that reason it is called perfuming.

When the perfuming consciousnesses, etc., are born from seeds, they are able to act as causes and perfume and form new seeds. The three dharmas, seed, cause, and result, occur simultaneously, just as a candle wick produces flame and the flame produces a burning wick, or just as bundles of reeds support each other.
Cause and effect occur simultaneously, and the principle is not shaken.
The perfuming produces seeds, and seeds give rise to actual dharmas, like the primary effect of a similar cause.
Seeds of the same species give rise to each other, like a homogeneous cause attracting a similar effect.

These two are the conditions as cause of their effects. Apart from these two, other dharmas are not conditions as cause. Even if they are called conditions as cause, you should know that this is a concession.
This is a brief explanation of the characteristics of all seeds.
What are the mode of activity and object of perception of this consciousness?
It is said that its mode of activity and object of perception are imperceptible, appropriating, and perceiving of a location.
Perceiving refers to perception, which is the mode of activity. Because consciousness has the mode of activity of perceiving,
location refers to the location, which is the world receptacle, because it is the location that supports all sentient beings.
There are two kinds of appropriation, namely, seeds and a body with organs.
Seeds refers to the habit energies of images, names, and discrimination.
A body with organs refers to material organs and the location of the organs.
Both are appropriated by consciousness, because they are included in the self and share sameness of support and destiny with it.
Both appropriated and the objective realm are objects of perception.

The reason is that by the power of its causes and conditions, the Älaya consciousness is born and internally transforms itself into seeds and a body with organs, and externally it transforms itself into the world receptacle. It takes the transformed objects as its own objects of perception, because its mode of activity depends on them in order to arise.

However, when the substance of impure consciousnesses is born, they all appear as the images of objects and the ability to perceive objects.
You should understand that the dharmas associated with consciousness are the same way.
The image that resembles the object is called the seen part, and that which resembles the perceiving consciousness is called the seeing part.

If mind and mental activities have no seen part as an object, they would be unable to perceive their own objects, or else each one would be able to perceive everything, because the object of one would be the same as that of all, and the object of all would be the same as that of one.

If mind and its activities do not have the aspect of being able to grasp an object, they cannot grasp objects, just as they cannot grasp space, etc. Or, space, etc., would also be able to grasp objects. Therefore mind and its activities must have two aspects.
As a scripture says,
All is only cognition, and the cognized object is nonexistent.
The parts of the cognizer and the cognized are each turned spontaneously.

Those who hold that there are objects of perception apart from consciousness maintain that external objects are the perceived aspect, the image part is the mode of activity, and the seeing part is the thing, because it is the self-substance of mind and its activities.

Mind and its activities have the same support and object and are similar in mode of activity, but although the number of things is the same, their aspects are different, because consciousness, feeling, conceptualization, etc., are different in aspect.

Those who understand that there are no objects of perception apart from consciousness maintain that the image part is the perceived aspect, the seeing part is the mode of activity, and the thing is the self-substance that is the support of the image and seeing parts, which is the self-verifying part.
If this fourth part does not exist, one should not remember mind and mental activities, because if one does not experience an object, one cannot remember it.

Mind and mental activities are the same in their support, which is the sense base, and in their object, but they differ in their mode of activity, because their functions of perceiving, feeling, etc., are different. Although the number of their activities may be the same, their modes are different, because consciousness, feeling, etc., are different in substance.

However, when mind and mental activities arise, reason and evidence show that each has three parts, because there is a difference among the perceived object, the perceiving activity, and the result of perception. The image and seeing must have a substance that supports them.

If this fourth part does not exist, what verifies the third part?
Since the part of mind is the same, it must be the result of all of them.

The part that authenticates the authenticating part only has as its object the third part and not the second, because it has no use.

The third and fourth parts are categorized as direct perception. The term realm means that consciousness as retribution, by the power of the maturation of its common seeds, transforms and appears as the characteristics of the world of the container, such as form, etc., i.e., the external great elements and the derivative form.

Even though what is transformed by each sentient being is separate, the characteristics are similar and the location is not different, just as the light of many lamps is each distinct but all together form one bright area.
Whose consciousness as retribution transforms into these characteristics?
There is an interpretation by Sthiramati that it is the consciousness of all sentient beings.
Why is this?
Because a scripture says,
All sentient beings, through the power of the dominant collective karma, create the world of the container.

There is an interpretation by DharmapÄla that if this were so, then Buddhas and bodhisattvas would really transform this impure world, and ordinary beings would really transform the pure lands of other regions and this world.
Also, when holy beings who are disgusted with form are born in the formless realm, they certainly do not descend to be born in this world and change into this land. What use would that be?
Therefore, those who now dwell in this world and those who will be born here transform this world through the perfuming of their own consciousness as retribution.
The scripture speaks of all beings on the basis of a part of the whole. All those whose karma is the same transform it together.

There is an interpretation by Sthiramati that if this were so, when the receptacle world is about to perish, there will be no one dwelling in it or about to be born there. Whose consciousness as retribution transforms into this world?
Also, when ordinary beings who are disgusted with form are born in the formless realm, they do not have a form body. What is the use of transforming the receptacle world in advance?
Even if they have a form body, it is far removed from the receptacle world of another stage and cannot be supported by it. What benefit is there in transforming it?
However, the transformed world is the support and enjoyment of the form body. Therefore, if it can support and be used by the body, it transforms into that body.
Consequently, even if one is born in another place in the same realm, the consciousness of that place can transform into this world.
Therefore, even though there are no sentient beings in the world at the beginning of a new kalpa or at the end of the old one, still the world exists.

This refers to the world that is experienced in common by all sentient beings. If it is experienced individually by a single sentient being, it must be understood to be the result of his own individual karma. This is so because ghosts, humans, and gods see it differently.
Seeds means all the impure seeds held by the consciousness that is retribution. They are categorized as consciousness and therefore are its objects.

Even though pure seeds are attached to this consciousness, they are not categorized as consciousness and therefore are not its objects. Even though they are not its objects, they are not separate from it, just as the nature of suchness is not, and this does not contradict the principle of consciousness only.

Body with organs means that as a result of the power of the maturation of seeds of consciousness as retribution that are not common to all, consciousness changes and becomes the material organs and the place where the organs are housed, that is, the internal great elements and the derivative form.

As a result of the power of the maturation of common seeds, it also changes and becomes the organs and their places in the bodies of others. If this were not so, one would be unable to experience the objects of others.
